[http://www.natal.rn.gov.br Natal, Rio Grande do Norte] |footnotes = }} 'Natal'
(, Christmas) is the capital and largest city of Rio Grande do Norte, a
northeastern state in Brazil. As of the IBGE July 2009, the city had a total
population of 950,820 (1,363,547 in its Greater Natal). Natal is considered by
IPEA (Institute of Applied Economic Research of Brazil), the safest capital city
in the country. [http://www.rn.gov.br/sistemnoticias/noticias.as-
p?idnoticia=6431 Population of the city]

The implementation of the Via Costeira (Coastal Highway), 10 km
(5.5 mi) long avenue along the shore and the dunes, was the true starting
point for the beginning of tourist activity in the State in the 1980s. That is
where the main hotels of the capital city, Natal, are concentrated. Natal has
several tourist attractions and is famous for its natural beauty (such as the
crystalline waters of MaracajaÃº and the largest cashew tree in the world), for
its historical monuments and buildings (such as the Forte dos Reis Magos, the
Alberto MaranhÃ£o Theatre and Newton Navarro bridge), for its beaches (such as
Ponta Negra, Pipa and Genipabu) and also for its off-season carnival, the
Carnatal. The city also boasts the second largest urban park in Brazil, the
Parque das Dunas. [http://www.brasil-
natal.com.br/en/destinations_about_natal.php ]

It is the capital of Brazil closest to Africa and Europe, and the
Augusto Severo International Airport connects Natal with many Brazilian cities
and also operates some international flights. The city is one of the host cities
of the 2014 FIFA World Cup, for which Brazil is the host nation.
categories: Populated coastal places in Rio Grande do Norte
